titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Oversize Ms. Codex 712: Sermons

notesStmt.note: Description of contents of volume in Latin bound in front.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Collection of sermons and other works of St. John Chrysostom, plus a copy of a letter from St. Basil to St. Gregory (f. 1r-3v).

author.persName: Basil, Saint, Bishop of Caesarea, ca. 329-379

msItem.title: Sermo Sancti Iohanis Chrisostomi contra Iudeos feliciter [sermones sex], f. 4r
Adverssus Anomoeos q[uod] D[ominus] inco[m]prehenssibilis sit [sermones quinque], f. 57r
Ad Stagirium Arrepticium monacum [libri tres], f. 89v
Paradoxa Ioannis Chrisostomi : neminem ledi nisi a se ip[s]o, f. 139v

supportDesc.extent: 150 leaves : 275 x 200 (188 x 104) mm. bound to 285 x 203 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Paper, iii (19th-century paper) + 150 + ii (19th-century paper); [1-150] modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 39 long lines; ruled in ink and lead.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in a Gothic cursive script by 2 different hands (f. 1r-139v, 139v-149v).

decoDesc.decoNote: Alternating red and blue used for initials and paragraph markers.

binding.p: 19th-century leather with gold stamped coat of arms with the motto "Esse quam videri" on upper and lower covers.

origin.p: Written in Italy in the 15th century (Zacour-Hirsch).

history.provenance: Sold by Thomas Thorpe in 1836 (no. 58) to Sir Thomas Phillipps; Phillipps ms. 9471.

keywords.term: Christianity and other religions--Judaism--Early works to 1800
Monastic and religious life--Early works to 1800
